title: 109_hr1312
content: The Act titled "Assault Weapons Ban and Law Enforcement Protection Act of 2005" reinstates criminal provisions related to assault weapons and large capacity ammunition feeding devices for 10 years. The Act reinstates provisions of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 related to firearms, including assault weapons and large capacity ammunition feeding devices. The Act reinstates provisions related to firearms, including assault weapons, with a mandatory minimum sentence of 10 years for possessing a semiautomatic assault weapon. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term 'semiautomatic assault weapon' is defined as specific rifles including AK-47, AR-15, and others in the United States Code. The curr_chunk lists various semiautomatic rifles and pistols that are considered assault weapons, including Kel-Tec Sub Rifle, M1 Carbine, Saiga, SAR-8, SKS, Steyr AUG, Sturm, Ruger Mini-14, Tavor, Thompson 1927, Uzi, Calico M-110, MAC-10, Olympic Arms OA, TEC-9, and Uzi. The curr_chunk lists specific features that classify certain firearms as assault weapons, including semiautomatic rifles with detachable magazines, folding or telescoping stocks, threaded barrels, pistol grips, forward grips, and barrel shrouds. It also mentions semiautomatic rifles with fixed magazines that can hold more than 10 rounds, with an exception for tubular devices designed for specific use. The curr_chunk outlines specific criteria for classifying certain firearms as assault weapons, including semiautomatic pistols with detachable magazines, second pistol grips, threaded barrels, barrel shrouds, and fixed magazines with high capacities. The curr_chunk details additional criteria for classifying assault weapons, including shotguns with revolving cylinders, frames or receivers similar to specified firearms, conversion kits, and semiautomatic rifles or shotguns not suitable for sporting purposes. The curr_chunk defines terms related to firearms, including "barrel shroud" and "conversion kit," with specific criteria for classifying assault weapons. The curr_chunk defines terms related to firearms, including detachable magazine, fixed magazine, folding or telescoping stock, forward grip, and pistol grip. The curr_chunk defines "pistol grip" as a grip or thumbhole stock that can function as a grip, and "threaded barrel" as a feature designed to allow attachment of a firearm. SEC. 4. GRANDFATHER PROVISION. Amends Section 922(v)(2) of title 18, United States Code to exempt firearms lawfully possessed before the enactment of this provision from certain restrictions. SEC. 5. REPEAL OF CERTAIN EXEMPTIONS. SEC. 5. REPEAL OF CERTAIN EXEMPTIONS. Amends Section 922(v)(3) of title 18, United States Code to exclude certain firearms from restrictions, including manually operated firearms, permanently inoperable firearms, and antique firearms. Section 922(v) of title 18, United States Code, prohibits the transfer of semiautomatic assault weapons except through licensed dealers or law enforcement agencies. The Attorney General must maintain records of these weapons. The Attorney General must maintain records of any semiautomatic assault weapon used in a crime under Federal or State law, and submit an annual report to Congress and the public. SEC. 7. STRENGTHENING THE BAN ON LARGE CAPACITY AMMUNITION FEEDING DEVICES. The text chunk discusses the ban on transferring assault weapons with large capacity ammunition feeding devices and the penalties for violating this ban. It also mentions the certification requirement for such transfers. The text chunk amends regulations regarding the transfer of large capacity ammunition feeding devices and imposes penalties for non-compliance. The text chunk adds penalties for knowingly violating regulations on large capacity ammunition feeding devices, including fines and imprisonment up to 5 years. SEC. 8 amends Section 922(x) of title 18, United States Code to include semiautomatic assault weapons and large capacity ammunition feeding devices in unlawful weapons transfers to juveniles. SEC. 9 imposes a ban on the importation of large capacity ammunition feeding devices. SEC. 9 imposes a ban on importing large capacity ammunition feeding devices into the United States.
